text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
-- Credit Foncier de France seeks partners, bank Deutsche Morgan Grenfell makes terms available from today.
-- Renault to sell shares in Elf Aquitaine oil group for an estimated 1.5 billion francs.
-- A licence granted to Axa-UAP for life insurance activities in China appears contradictory to prior agreements between Axa and Australian authorities when Axa bought National Mutual.
-- Both political sides agree to the need for a consensus toward joining the European single currency.
-- Terms and conditions prepared by the finance ministry for the planned privatisation of CIC is less restrictive than at time of first attempted privatisation in November 1996.
-- Shareholding structure at Total expected to undergo changes, as shareholders' pact linking CDR, AGF and GAN ends today.
-- Credit Lyonnais seems in a good position to be privatised faster than expected; sources said British and U.S.- based investors have expressed interest in the state-owned bank.
-- State to bail out French overseas territory's bank Credit Martiniquais with an estimated 300-million-francs injection.
-- Elf Aquitaine shares rose 2.5 percent yesterday after it bought back 0.9 percent of its shares from carmaker Renault, and on expectations it may buy back further shares.
